speaker: Subject

text: Last winter, I had the pleasure of composing a somatic exercise
speaker: Subject

text: with my friend ~C ~A Conrad
speaker: Subject

text: Our exercise was based on downtown New York City cellist Arthur Russell's masterpiece, World of Echo.
speaker: Subject

text: It is difficult to describe Russell's World of Echo for anyone who hasn't heard it before
speaker: Subject

text: It has a rare spiritual quality, which issues from Russell's songwriting, voice and cello playing, but also from the production values of the album
speaker: Subject

text: Perhaps the following passage from Tim Lawrence's biography of Russell, Hold Onto Your Dreams makes palpable Russell's subtle, accidental studio processes.
speaker: Subject

text: During these sessions it became standard for Arthur to splice together separate tapes
speaker: Subject

text: and he would regularly grab a track from one tape and fly it into the multitrack of another while his onlooking engineer tried to stay calm
speaker: Subject

text: Quote
speaker: Subject

text: We would be mixing on a piece of tape and I would see the splice go by, recalls Eric Liljestrand
speaker: Subject

text: It was all very confusing. I could never really tell what we were working on until it was done,
speaker: Subject

text: unquote
speaker: Subject

text: The ghostly accidents that arose from Arthur's insistence that they rerecord over old tape became= became an integral+ part of the sonic fabric
speaker: Subject

text: At one point, Conrad told me that he used the album to heal a knee injury that he had suffered
speaker: Subject

text: Russell was trained foremost as a musician and only afterwards as a Buddhist. So the healing powers of his music I can only imagine come from the confluence of these two disciplines.
speaker: Subject

text: For our exercise, Conrad and I decided to have Russell's album playing on four different stereos throughout the five story house for a twelve hour duration
speaker: Subject

text: Twelve hours is a long time to do anything, ((and)) especially to listen to an album ((triply)) on repeat.
speaker: Subject

text: Among the constraints I recall imposing on myself,
speaker: Subject

text: many had to do with memory.
speaker: Subject

text: Trying to forget the last line I had written before continuing
speaker: Subject

text: Interrupting myself mid line, then picking up with the line again
speaker: Subject

text: These exercises in intention and distraction I felt were true to Russell's music
speaker: Subject

text: So was a certain circularity that the exercises were trying to induce amidst interruption and disjunction
speaker: Subject

text: We also spent much of the nine hours improvising lines with a set of books I had brought with me from New York City to Philadelphia
speaker: Subject

text: many of which were of a wholly metaphysical or medical import
speaker: Subject

text: Among these books included the writings of Henry Corbin and his acolyte Christian Jambet
speaker: Subject

text: Oliver Sacks's Seeing Voices,
speaker: Subject

text: Maurice Merleau Ponty's selected writings on phenomenology
speaker: Subject

text: a collection of Gaelic folktales and ballads,
speaker: Subject

text: Hellen Keller's autobiography
speaker: Subject

text: Robert ((Koch's)) Rhubarb
speaker: Subject

text: and the Tibetan Book of the Dead
I also remember reading a number of recently published poetry books including Jules Boykoff's courageous Hegemonic Love Potion
speaker: Subject

text: Russell, perhaps more than any other composer I'd come into contact with
speaker: Subject

text: understood the importance of tuning his body and his mind as instruments coeval with his cello and the other instruments, drum machines, guitar, tabla he would use throughout his compositions.
speaker: Subject

text: Via studio production Russell gave access to the occult and otherworldly in ways similar to Conrad's use of his own body as a source of information and vision
speaker: Subject

text: explored through the somatic exercise
speaker: Subject

text: And to conclude, I'd like to read um my contribution
speaker: Subject

text: to this um little book which um Conrad has a few copies of
